article: I first met Sean one summer day. He carried a bag _ with four clubs and some balls. He was a lot _ than other kids of his age. I heard he was _ from cancer. Still , he always seemed to be smiling whenever I would see him with his friends, trying to _ as far as he did. A year or so passed and I hadn t _ Sean .I had heard that his cancer was _ him. Still, his friends said he was going to come here before long. _ enough , he was there the following week. I _ that one of his friends was carrying Sean s bag. I saw Sean was having a(n) _ time trying to drive the ball. Sean hit his last ball as hard as his fragile body would _ .It flew up to the green and was out of sight. One of his friends _ Sean walk up to the green. It was a(n) _ walk because the green was higher than the tee. Suddenly I saw one boy pick up Sean s ball and _ it in the hole. Then he ran and _ to look for his own ball. When Sean finally got to the green, he looked _ because he thought he hit it over .Then he glanced in the hole. A smile _ his face! The boys looked at each other and said , You can t tell me it s a hole-in-one! No, really ! Look ! he said . They all acted _ and as I watched , I thought Sean looked like the _ guy I had ever seen. I never saw Sean or his friends after that day. _ it was then that I learned just what golf should be . It s not about what _ you get or how far you drive. It is about caring for the friends you play with and enjoying the time you have with them.
